oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Columbia Union Station Depot: Front (north) facade view
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Eatherly, Brad, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of a train station viewed from the north. The foundation is a brick and stone material. The front facade is asymmetrical with two double-leaf entries with wood-and-glass doors. Above the two sets of doors are semi-circular hood molds with three-light transoms and traceried muntins. Geometrical bas-relief decorations dominate the entryways. Two one-over-one double-hung sash windows are located to the east of the doorways and three one-over-one double-hung windows are located to the west of the doorways. Corbeling surround each set of windows. The second floor is separated by a raised stone cornice. Eight one-over-one double-hung sash windows are located on the second story. Eight small rectangular fixed single light attic windows cap the second story windows. A tin cornice with dentils tops the entire facade. A hipped corrugated tin roof sits atop the structure.

The Columbia Union Station train depot was built from 1902-1905 by the Nashville, Chattanooga, and St. Louis Railway and the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. It operated as a passenger service depot until 1954 when airline travel became more popular and as a freight depot until 1961, at which time it became unused as a station. It was used as cheap apartments in the 1970s and 1980s until it fell into disrepair. It was restored in the early 2010s.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Railroad stations
